Introduction

Dynamic problems are dynamic because of the following

  1. Time-varying nature of load: Not a single solution, but solution at different times of interest
  2. Inertial effect of dynamic response: internal moment, shear, and deflection shape depend on load an inertial force opposing them. If inertial force significantly contributes to the structure response, dynamic investigation could be required.

Several forms of dynamic loads are machinery, earthquake, footfall, vehicle, and impact. There are 2 types:

  • Prescribed: exact representaiton of load is available. Deterministic analysis is used
  • Stochastic loading: inherently uncertain in magnitude and time variation. Non-deterministic analysis used

Problems are solved by taking a physical system and breaking it down into an analytical model, and then a mathematical model. Analytical models are either continuous or discrete. Continuous results in the exact representation of the displacement and have infinite DOF. Discrete parameter models are lumped mass models with finite DOF. Single degree of freedom (SDOF) models have mass lumped at a single point

Distributed parameter models lead to PDEs; for the cantilever problem, the governing PDF is ∂2∂x2[EI(x)∂2v(x,t)∂x2+m(x)∂2v∂t2]=P(x,t)\frac{\partial^2}{\partial{x^2}}[EI(x)\frac{\partial^2v(x,t)}{\partial{x^2}}+m(x)\frac{\partial^2v}{\partial{t^2}}]=P(x,t)∂x2∂2​[EI(x)∂x2∂2v(x,t)​+m(x)∂t2∂2v​]=P(x,t). The SDOF lumped parameter model simplifies this to an ODE m∂2v∂t2+kv(t)=P(t)m\frac{\partial^2v}{\partial{t^2}}+kv(t)=P(t)m∂t2∂2v​+kv(t)=P(t)

Single-Degree-of-Freedom System

SDOF systems require a mass and an elastic component. Mass stores and releases kinetic energy, while elastic component stores and releases potential energy.

Springs are modelled to relate force to deformation. A linear relationship exists between force and elongation or contraction fs=k(u2−u1)f_s=k(u_2-u_1)fs​=k(u2​−u1​). This is true for several examples:

  1. Axial deformation: P=AELδP=\frac{AE}{L}\deltaP=LAE​δ, with k=AELk=\frac{AE}{L}k=LAE​
  2. Cantilever beam: P=3EIL3δP=\frac{3EI}{L^3}\deltaP=L33EI​δ, with k=3EIL3k=\frac{3EI}{L^3}k=L33EI​
  3. Simply Supported beam: P=48EIL3δP=\frac{48EI}{L^3}\deltaP=L348EI​δ, with k=48EIL3k=\frac{48EI}{L^3}k=L348EI​

Dampers are also included in models. A viscous damping element is a damper that dissipates mechanical energy. The 3 main sources of damping include:

  • Mechanical damping, such as microcracks in concrete and yielding of steel
  • Interfacial damping, such as friction between connectors
  • Aerodynamic damping, such as water and offshore structure

Generally, viscous dampers work like a force in a fluid. Damping force is given by fD=c(u2˙−u1˙)f_D=c(\dot{u_2}-\dot{u_1})fD​=c(u2​˙​−u1​˙​) as the dashpot model relates several velocities to each other. c is the coefficient of viscous damping, with Nsm\frac{Ns}{m}mNs​ as the unit. See model below:

From this, mass, stiffness, and damping are all components of a SDOF model. Mass is related to inertial force according to D'Alembert's Principle. According to Newton's 2nd law, ∑F⃗=ddt(mx˙)\sum{\vec{F}}=\frac{d}{dt}(m\dot{x})∑F=dtd​(mx˙). It follows that ∑F+FI=0\sum{F}+F_I=0∑F+FI​=0. Thus, FI=−mx¨F_I=-m\ddot{x}FI​=−mx¨. We can say that fs=kuf_s=kufs​=ku, fI=mu¨f_I=m\ddot{u}fI​=mu¨, fD=cu˙f_D=c\dot{u}fD​=cu˙, and P(t) is the applied force. In equilibrium, P(t)−mu¨−cu˙−ku=0P(t)-m\ddot{u}-c\dot{u}-ku=0P(t)−mu¨−cu˙−ku=0. Expanded, the below is true, with mass, m (kg), stiffness, k (kN/m), and damping, c (kNs/m):

mu¨(t)+cu˙(t)+ku(t)=P(t)m\ddot{u}(t)+c\dot{u}(t)+ku(t)=P(t) mu¨(t)+cu˙(t)+ku(t)=P(t)

For a rotated bar, the inertial force is given by FI=μdx(y¨(t)2xL)F_I=\mu{dx}(\ddot{y}(t)\frac{2x}{L})FI​=μdx(y¨​(t)L2x​) (Complete Proof). Now, by the small angle theorum, θ(t)≈2y(t)L\theta(t)\approx\frac{2y(t)}{L}θ(t)≈L2y(t)​ and θ¨=2y¨L\ddot{\theta}=\frac{2\ddot{y}}{L}θ¨=L2y¨​​. Thus, y¨=θ¨L2\ddot{y}=\frac{\ddot{\theta}L}{2}y¨​=2θ¨L​. The inertial force is not fI=μθx¨dxf_I=\mu\ddot{\theta_x}dxfI​=μθx​¨​dx.

Further, the moment is taken about the centre of mass G. m=∫L/2L/2μθ¨x2dxm=\int^{L/2}_{L/2}\mu\ddot{\theta}x^2dxm=∫L/2L/2​μθ¨x2dx. Now, the mass moment of inertia IG=μ∫L/2L/2x2dxI_G=\mu\int^{L/2}_{L/2}x^2dxIG​=μ∫L/2L/2​x2dx. This, mG=IGθ¨m_G=I_G\ddot{\theta}mG​=IG​θ¨.

Gravity consideration

If gravity is considered, letting ut(t)u^t(t)ut(t) be the total discplacement from static equilibrium, mg is a static position. Thus, when taking the derivative of displacement and velocity, the mg goes away. In this sense, ut˙=u˙\dot{u^t}=\dot{u}ut˙=u˙. See diagram below:

Also note that the initial stretch, Δst=mgk\Delta_{st}=\frac{mg}{k}Δst​=kmg​. When placed into the equation mu(t)¨+cu˙+k[u(t)+Δst]=P(t)+mgm\ddot{u(t)}+c\dot{u}+k[u(t)+\Delta_{st}]=P(t)+mgmu(t)¨​+cu˙+k[u(t)+Δst​]=P(t)+mg, the mg term cancels out on both sides. Thus, only considering relative velocity and forgetting about mg is the best approach.

Ground-excitation

For a SDOF frame, total displacement uT=us+uGu_T=u_s+u_GuT​=us​+uG​, with usu_sus​ being structure displacement and uGu_GuG​ being ground displacement. The forces acting are as follows:

  • fD=cus˙(t)=c(uT˙−uG˙f_D=c\dot{u_s}(t)=c(\dot{u_T}-\dot{u_G}fD​=cus​˙​(t)=c(uT​˙​−uG​˙​
  • fs=k(uT˙−ug˙)=kus˙f_s=k(\dot{u_T}-\dot{u_g})=k\dot{u_s}fs​=k(uT​˙​−ug​˙​)=kus​˙​

Altogether, m(ug¨+us¨(t))+cus˙+kus(t)=P(t)m(\ddot{u_g}+\ddot{u_s}(t))+c\dot{u_s}+ku_s(t)=P(t)m(ug​¨​+us​¨​(t))+cus​˙​+kus​(t)=P(t). For simplicity, the ug¨m\ddot{u_g}mug​¨​m term should be brought over to the left. See FBD below:

Natural Frequency

Dividing the equation of motion by m, we know x¨(t)+cmx˙(t)+kmx(t)=P(t)m\ddot{x}(t)+\frac{c}{m}\dot{x}(t)+\frac{k}{m}x(t)=\frac{P(t)}{m}x¨(t)+mc​x˙(t)+mk​x(t)=mP(t)​. ωn2=km\omega{n^2}=\frac{k}{m}ωn2=mk​; the undamped circular natural frequency is the square root, with units rads/s. See below:

ωn=km(Undamped circular natural frequency)\omega_n=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}\tag{Undamped circular natural frequency} ωn​=mk​​(Undamped circular natural frequency)

  • ωn=2πfn\omega_n=2\pi{f_n}ωn​=2πfn​, where fnf_nfn​ is the natural frequency of the structure in cycles per second (Hz)
  • ωn=2πTn\omega_n=\frac{2\pi}{T_n}ωn​=Tn​2π​, where TnT_nTn​ is the natural period of the structure (s)

Importantly, the viscous damping factor, ζ\zetaζ, is also defined below (it is unitless):

ζ=c2km=CCcr(Viscous damping factor)\zeta=\frac{c}{2\sqrt{km}}\tag{Viscous damping factor}=\frac{C}{C_{cr}} ζ=2km​c​=Ccr​C​(Viscous damping factor)

  • CcrC_{cr}Ccr​ is the critical damping coefficient. Ccr=2km=2mωnC_{cr}=2\sqrt{km}=2m\omega_nCcr​=2km​=2mωn​.

ωn\omega_nωn​ and ζ\zetaζ can be subbed into the equation of motion, such as below (Examples):

x¨(t)+2ζωnx˙(t)+ωn2x(t)=ωn2P(t)k\ddot{x}(t)+2\zeta\omega_n\dot{x}(t)+\omega_n^2x(t)=\omega_n^2\frac{P(t)}{k} x¨(t)+2ζωn​x˙(t)+ωn2​x(t)=ωn2​kP(t)​

Free vibration

The following can be determined using calculus (See here for full proof):

x(t)=x(0)cos⁡ωnt+x˙(0)ωnsin⁡ωnt(Undamped Free Vibration)x(t)=x(0)\cos\omega_nt+\frac{\dot{x}(0)}{\omega_n}\sin\omega_nt\tag{Undamped Free Vibration} x(t)=x(0)cosωn​t+ωn​x˙(0)​sinωn​t(Undamped Free Vibration)

  • A=x(0)2+[x˙(0)ωn]2A=\sqrt{x(0)^2+[\frac{\dot{x}(0)}{\omega_n}]^2}A=x(0)2+[ωn​x˙(0)​]2​
  • In amplitude phase form, this is rewritten as x(t)=Acos⁡(ωnt−ϕ)x(t)=A\cos{(\omega_nt-\phi)}x(t)=Acos(ωn​t−ϕ). See image below:

Viscously damped free vibration depends on whether the system is underdamped, overdamped, or critically damped.

As a result of damping, the natural frequency and period change.

  • The damped natural frequency, ωD=ωn1−ζ2\omega_D=\omega_n\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}ωD​=ωn​1−ζ2​. The

In the underdamped case, ζ<1\zeta<1ζ<1. The displacement is determined with the below:

x(t)=e−ζωnt[x0cos⁡ωDt+v0+ζωnx0ωDsin⁡ωDT](Underdamped displacement)x(t)=e^{-\zeta\omega_nt}[x_0\cos\omega_Dt+\frac{v_0+\zeta\omega_nx_0}{\omega_D}\sin\omega_DT]\tag{Underdamped displacement} x(t)=e−ζωn​t[x0​cosωD​t+ωD​v0​+ζωn​x0​​sinωD​T](Underdamped displacement)

  • Alternatively, x(t)=A(t=t1)e−ζωDtx(t)=A(t=t_1)e^{-\zeta\omega_Dt}x(t)=A(t=t1​)e−ζωD​t with A=x02+(v0+ζωnx0ωD)2A=\sqrt{x_0^2+(\frac{v_0+\zeta\omega_nx_0}{\omega_D})^2}A=x02​+(ωD​v0​+ζωn​x0​​)2​

In the overdamped case, ζ>1\zeta>1ζ>1. The displacement is determined with the below:

x(t)=e−ζωnt[x0cosh[(ωn∗t)+v0+ζωnx0ωn∗sinh(ωn∗t)](Overdamped displacement)x(t)=e^{-\zeta\omega_nt}[x_0\textrm{cosh}[(\omega_n* t)+\frac{v_0+\zeta\omega_nx_0}{\omega_n*}\textrm{sinh}(\omega_n* t)]\tag{Overdamped displacement} x(t)=e−ζωn​t[x0​cosh[(ωn​∗t)+ωn​∗v0​+ζωn​x0​​sinh(ωn​∗t)](Overdamped displacement)

In the critically damped case, ζ=1\zeta=1ζ=1/ The displacement is determined with the below:

x(t)=e∗−ωnt[x0+(v0+ωnx0)](Critically damped displacement)x(t)=e*{-\omega_nt}[x_0+(v_0+\omega_nx_0)]\tag{Critically damped displacement} x(t)=e∗−ωn​t[x0​+(v0​+ωn​x0​)](Critically damped displacement)

For civil engineering, ζ≈0\zeta\approx{0}ζ≈0. Thus, in the typical underdamped situation, ζ\zetaζ can be calculated with some simplifying assumptions. ln⁡[x(t)x(t+TD)]=δ=2πζ1−ζ2\ln{[\frac{x(t)}{x(t+T_D)}]}=\delta=\frac{2\pi\zeta}{\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}}ln[x(t+TD​)x(t)​]=δ=1−ζ2​2πζ​. This is approximated as per the below:

δ≈2πζ\delta\approx{2\pi\zeta} δ≈2πζ

In scenarios when there are multiply cycles, δ=ln⁡(xixi+N)N=2πζ\delta=\frac{\ln{(\frac{x_i}{x_{i+N}})}}{N}=2\pi\zetaδ=Nln(xi+N​xi​​)​=2πζ. See the figure below to demonstrate this:

Harmonic Excitation

Forced motion includes structures subjected to a harmonic excitation. The response to harmonic excitation is important because many structures, such as rotating machinery, are subject to such motion. It is also the basis for experimental structural dynamics and is useful for identifying frequencies and damping in experimental studies.

The equation of motion for an undamped SDOF system is Mx¨+kx=P(t)M\ddot{x}+kx=P(t)Mx¨+kx=P(t). Considering a harmonic system, P(t)=O0sin⁡ωtP(t)=O_0\sin{\omega{t}}P(t)=O0​sinωt with solutions x(t)=xc(t)+xp(t)x(t)=x_c(t)+x_p(t)x(t)=xc​(t)+xp​(t).

As with free vibration, the complementary solution is as follows:

xc(t)=A1cos⁡(ωnt)+A2sin⁡(ωnt)x_c(t)=A_1\cos{(\omega_nt)}+A_2\sin{(\omega_nt)} xc​(t)=A1​cos(ωn​t)+A2​sin(ωn​t)

The particular solution is determined by assuming the harmonic excitation has harmonic motion and is in-phase. The particular solution is assumed to be xp(t)=Csin⁡(ωt)x_p(t)=C\sin{(\omega{t})}xp​(t)=Csin(ωt). By substituting the particular solution into the SDOF equation of motion, it can be shown that −Cmω2sin⁡ωt+Cksin⁡(ωt)=P0sin⁡(ωt),C[k−mω2]sin⁡ωt=P0sin⁡(ωt)-Cm\omega^2\sin\omega{t}+Ck\sin{(\omega{t})}=P_0\sin{(\omega{t})}, C[k-m\omega^2]\sin\omega_t=P_0\sin{(\omega{t})}−Cmω2sinωt+Cksin(ωt)=P0​sin(ωt),C[k−mω2]sinωt​=P0​sin(ωt). The following results are determined:

P0=C[k−mω2]P_0=C[k-m\omega^2] P0​=C[k−mω2]

C=P0k−mω2C=\frac{P_0}{k-m\omega^2} C=k−mω2P0​​

The particular solution is thus determined to be xp(t)=P0sin⁡ωtk−mω2x_p(t)=\frac{P_0\sin\omega{t}}{k-m\omega^2}xp​(t)=k−mω2P0​sinωt​. Since km=ωn2\frac{k}{m}=\omega_n^2mk​=ωn2​, we can say the below:

xp(t)=P0sin⁡ωtk[1−(ωωn)2]x_p(t)=\frac{P_0\sin\omega{t}}{k[1-(\frac{\omega}{\omega_n})^2]} xp​(t)=k[1−(ωn​ω​)2]P0​sinωt​

THE GIST OF THIS is that xc(t)x_c(t)xc​(t) is the transient response. In other words, it is the response for free vibration and depends on:

  • Initial condition
  • Vibrates at ωn\omega_nωn​, and decays with damping

xp(t)x_p(t)xp​(t) is the steady state response, and depends on the following:

  • Excitation
  • Vibrates at ω\omegaω (forcing frequency), and continues as long as there is input excitation

A1=x0A_1=x_0A1​=x0​ is determined using x(0)=x0x(0)=x_0x(0)=x0​ and A2=v0ωn−P0ωωnk[1−(ωωn)2]A_2=\frac{v_0}{\omega_n}-\frac{P_0\frac{\omega}{\omega_n}}{k[1-(\frac{\omega}{\omega_n})^2]}A2​=ωn​v0​​−k[1−(ωn​ω​)2]P0​ωn​ω​​ is determined with x˙(0)=v0\dot{x}(0)=v_0x˙(0)=v0​. Altogether, the complete solution is given by the following:

x(t)=A1cos⁡ωnt+A2sin⁡ωnt+P0k[1−(ωωn)2]sin⁡ωtx(t)=A_1\cos{\omega_nt}+A_2\sin{\omega_nt}+\frac{P_0}{k[1-(\frac{\omega}{\omega_n})^2]}\sin\omega{t} x(t)=A1​cosωn​t+A2​sinωn​t+k[1−(ωn​ω​)2]P0​​sinωt

The amplification factor is found by looking at the steady state response of undamped systems. Using the equation for xp(t)x_p(t)xp​(t), letting xst=P0kx_{st}=\frac{P_0}{k}xst​=kP0​​, we have xp(t)xst=11−(ωωn)2sin⁡ωt\frac{x_p(t)}{x_{st}}=\frac{1}{1-(\frac{\omega}{\omega_n})^2}\sin\omega{t}xst​xp​(t)​=1−(ωn​ω​)21​sinωt. Since the maximum value of sin⁡ωt=1\sin\omega{t}=1sinωt=1, we can say the below:

∣AF∣=11−(ωωn)2|AF|=\frac{1}{1-(\frac{\omega}{\omega_n})^2} ∣AF∣=1−(ωn​ω​)21​

It is important to tnote that when ωωn<1\frac{\omega}{\omega_n}<1ωn​ω​<1, the factor 11−(ωωn)2\frac{1}{1-(\frac{\omega}{\omega_n})^2}1−(ωn​ω​)21​ is positive. Thus, u(t) and p(t) would have the same sign and displacement direction; the displacement would be in phase with the applied force. If ωωn>1\frac{\omega}{\omega_n}>1ωn​ω​>1, the factor is negative and out of phase.

Resonant frequency: forcing frequency at which ∣AF∣|AF|∣AF∣ is maximum. For undamped, this equals ωn\omega_nωn​. For at-rest conditions, the equation of motion is below:

u(t)=P0(sinωnt−ωntcos⁡ωnt)2ku(t)=\frac{P_0(sin\omega_nt-\omega_nt\cos\omega_nt)}{2k} u(t)=2kP0​(sinωn​t−ωn​tcosωn​t)​

This motion is shown, graphed below:

Considering viscious damped SDOF systems, the equation of motion x¨+2ζωnx˙+ωn2x=P0ωn2sin⁡ωtk\ddot{x}+2\zeta\omega_n\dot{x}+\omega_n^2x=\frac{P_0\omega_n^2\sin\omega{t}}{k}x¨+2ζωn​x˙+ωn2​x=kP0​ωn2​sinωt​. According the derivation (see here), the squation of motion is below (let ϕ=ωωn\phi=\frac{\omega}{\omega_n}ϕ=ωn​ω​ and xst=P0kx_{st}=\frac{P_0}{k}xst​=kP0​​):

x(t)=e−ζωnt(Acos⁡ωDt+Dsin⁡ωDt)+xst[1−ϕ2(1−ϕ2)2+4ζ2ϕ2sin⁡ωt−2ζϕ(1−ϕ2)2+4ζ2ϕ2cos⁡ωt]x(t)=e^{-\zeta\omega_nt}(A\cos\omega_Dt+D\sin\omega_Dt)+x_{st}[\frac{1-\phi^2}{(1-\phi^2)^2+4\zeta^2\phi^2}\sin\omega{t}-\frac{2\zeta\phi}{(1-\phi^2)^2+4\zeta^2\phi^2}\cos\omega{t}] x(t)=e−ζωn​t(AcosωD​t+DsinωD​t)+xst​[(1−ϕ2)2+4ζ2ϕ21−ϕ2​sinωt−(1−ϕ2)2+4ζ2ϕ22ζϕ​cosωt]

If the first term (transient) decays with time, it can be assumed to be neglected. In amplitude-phase form (α=tan⁡−12ζϕ1−ϕ2\alpha=\tan^{-1}\frac{2\zeta\phi}{1-\phi^2}α=tan−11−ϕ22ζϕ​), x(t)xst=sin⁡(ωt−α)(1−ϕ2)2+4ζ2ϕ2\frac{x(t)}{x_{st}}=\frac{\sin{(\omega{t}-\alpha)}}{\sqrt{(1-\phi^2)^2+4\zeta^2\phi^2}}xst​x(t)​=(1−ϕ2)2+4ζ2ϕ2​sin(ωt−α)​. The amplification factor is then given by the below when ω=ωn\omega=\omega_nω=ωn​:

∣AF∣=xmaxxst=12ζ|AF|=\frac{x_{max}}{x_{st}}=\frac{1}{2\zeta} ∣AF∣=xst​xmax​​=2ζ1​

The responant frequency for visciously damped SDOF systems is ωresωn=1−2ζ2\omega_{res}{\omega_n}=\sqrt{1-2\zeta^2}ωres​ωn​=1−2ζ2​. Plugging into a previous equation, se can say:

∣AF∣max=12ζ1−ζ2|AF|_{max}=\frac{1}{2\zeta\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}} ∣AF∣max​=2ζ1−ζ2​1​

While this is accurate, generally if ζ<0.05\zeta<0.05ζ<0.05, it is okay that ∣AF∣max=12ζ|AF|_{max}=\frac{1}{2\zeta}∣AF∣max​=2ζ1​

The half-bandwidth method is an alternative to the logarithmic decrament method that can be used to determine ζ\zetaζ. See below to visualize a half-bandwidth:

From the derivation, se get the below:

ωωn≈1±ζ\frac{\omega}{\omega_n}\approx{1\pm\zeta} ωn​ω​≈1±ζ

To determine ζ\zetaζ experimentally,

  1. Harmonically excite over a wide range of ω\omegaω
  2. Generate frequency response plot
  3. From ∣AF∣max|AF|_{max}∣AF∣max​, estimate ωn\omega_nωn​
  4. Find ∣AF∣max2\frac{|AF|_{max}}{\sqrt{2}}2​∣AF∣max​​ points
  5. Determine ωa\omega_aωa​ and ωb\omega_bωb​. Then, ζ=ωb−ωa2ωn\zeta=\frac{\omega_b-\omega_a}{2\omega_n}ζ=2ωn​ωb​−ωa​​

Force Transmissibility and Base Motion

Force transmissibility: force transmitted through spring and damper into fixed base

Base Motion: how much ground motion is imparted into mass

From the FBD above, the total force transmitted to the base at time t, is written as FTR(t)=kx(t)+cx˙=k[x(t)+cx˙(t)k]F_{TR}(t)=kx(t)+c\dot{x}=k[x(t)+\frac{c\dot{x}(t)}{k}]FTR​(t)=kx(t)+cx˙=k[x(t)+kcx˙(t)​]. Using the equation for x(t)x(t)x(t) previously defined for harmonic excitation, we get the below:

FTR(t)=P0[sin⁡(ωt−α)+2ζϕcos⁡(ωt−α)](1−ϕ2)2+4ζ2ϕ2F_{TR}(t)=\frac{P_0[\sin{(\omega{t}-\alpha)}+2\zeta\phi\cos{(\omega{t}-\alpha)}]}{\sqrt{(1-\phi^2)^2+4\zeta^2\phi^2}} FTR​(t)=(1−ϕ2)2+4ζ2ϕ2​P0​[sin(ωt−α)+2ζϕcos(ωt−α)]​

  • The sin⁡\sinsin term is fsf_sfs​ and the cos⁡\coscos term is fDf_DfD​

The max FTR(t)F_{TR}(t)FTR​(t) is given below:

FTRmax=P01+4ζ2ϕ2(1−ϕ2)2+4ζ2ϕ2F_{TR_{max}}=P_0\sqrt{\frac{1+4\zeta^2\phi^2}{(1-\phi^2)^2+4\zeta^2\phi^2}} FTRmax​​=P0​(1−ϕ2)2+4ζ2ϕ21+4ζ2ϕ2​​

The transmissibility, or TRTRTR, is FTRP0\frac{F_{TR}}{P_0}P0​FTR​​. Interestingly, while damping deecreases the amplitude of motion for all frequencies, it only decreases the transmitted force for ϕ<2\phi<\sqrt{2}ϕ<2​. For the transmitted force to be less than the applied force, the stiffness of the support or the natural frequency should be small enough such that ωωn<2\frac{\omega}{\omega_n}<\sqrt{2}ωn​ω​<2​. Damping is not required here, as it increases FTRF_{TR}FTR​. See plot below:

From the plot, is it evident that enough damping is required to pass through resonance. Amplification here is not too high. Also note that if the excitation frequency is much smaller than the natural frequency of the system, then the mass moves almost rigidly with the gorund, but undergoes the same acceleration. In contrast, when the excitation frequency is much larger than the natural frequency of the system, the mass stays still while the ground beneath moves. This is the premise of base isolation; the structure is isolated from a moving base using very flexible support system.

In the event that the base undergoes simple harmonic motion xg(t)=xg0sin⁡ωtx_g(t)=x_{g_0}\sin\omega{t}xg​(t)=xg0​​sinωt, the equation of motion is mx¨+cx+kx=−mxg¨(t)m\ddot{x}+cx+kx=-m\ddot{x_g}(t)mx¨+cx+kx=−mxg​¨​(t). From this, it can be shown that:

xt(t)=xg0ϕ2[(1−ϕ2+4ζ2ϕ2)sin⁡ωt−2ζϕ3cos⁡ωt](1−ϕ2)2+4ζ2ϕ2x_t(t)=\frac{x_{g_0}\phi^2[(1-\phi^2+4\zeta^2\phi^2)\sin{\omega{t}}-2\zeta\phi^3\cos\omega{t}]}{(1-\phi^2)^2+4\zeta^2\phi^2} xt​(t)=(1−ϕ2)2+4ζ2ϕ2xg0​​ϕ2[(1−ϕ2+4ζ2ϕ2)sinωt−2ζϕ3cosωt]​

TR=1+4ζ2ϕ2(1−ϕ2)2+4ζ2ϕ2TR=\sqrt{\frac{1+4\zeta^2\phi^2}{(1-\phi^2)^2+4\zeta^2\phi^2}} TR=(1−ϕ2)2+4ζ2ϕ21+4ζ2ϕ2​​

Equivalent Viscous Damping and Coulomb Damping

Equivalent viscous damping is related to the energy dissipaged by the actual damping mechanism. This is related to the energy dissipated by a viscous damper in the plot below:

The area of this ellipse is A=πη2cωA=\pi\eta^2c\omegaA=πη2cω, with η=P0uk\eta=\frac{P_0u}{k}η=kP0​u​ and ω\omegaω being the forcing frequency in a cycle t=2πωt=\frac{2\pi}{\omega}t=ω2π​. It is also equal to the work done by the damper. To find the viscous damping coefficient, the energy dissipated in one cycle of each system is equated to the expression for A.

Coulomb damping force: damping resistance provided by friction against sliding along a dry surface. This is proportional to the force acting normal to the contact surface and opposite the direction of motion. See below:

The equation of harmonic motion is given by mx¨(t)+kx(t)±μN=P0sin⁡ωtm\ddot{x}(t)+kx(t)\pm\mu{N}=P_0\sin\omega{t}mx¨(t)+kx(t)±μN=P0​sinωt. The positive is for friction when mass moving to right, negative when moving to the left. Equivalent viscous damping coefficient is found by equating energy loss per cycle to the energy loss in a viscous damper. See below:

Here, the work done by friction force is ωD=4μNπ\omega_D=4\mu{N}\piωD​=4μNπ. Relating the previously defined equation for viscous damping to this, we have the following:

Ceqπωη2=4μNηC_{eq}\pi\omega\eta^2=4\mu{N}\eta Ceq​πωη2=4μNη

Ceq=4μNπωηC_{eq}=\frac{4\mu{N}}{\pi\omega\eta} Ceq​=πωη4μN​

Arbitrary Excitations

It is more complicated to analyze a structure's response to a forcing function that is not harmonic. There are several functions of interest, however.

Response to Step Function Load

Step function load: suddenly applied load that remains constant after application. See below for example applied at t=0 (can be applied at other times)

Equation of motion here is mx¨+cx˙+kx=P0m\ddot{x}+c\dot{x}+kx=P_0mx¨+cx˙+kx=P0​. with complementary solution xc(t)=e−ζωnt[Acos⁡ωDt+Bsin⁡ωDt]x_c(t)=e^{-\zeta\omega_nt}[A\cos\omega_Dt+B\sin\omega_Dt]xc​(t)=e−ζωn​t[AcosωD​t+BsinωD​t] and particular solution xp=P0kx_p=\frac{P_0}{k}xp​=kP0​​. With initial conditions at t=0 equalling zero, we have:

x(t)=xst[1−e−ζωnt(cos⁡ωDt+ζsin⁡ωDt1−ζ2)]x(t)=x_{st}[1-e^{-\zeta\omega_nt}(\cos\omega_Dt+\frac{\zeta\sin\omega_Dt}{\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}})] x(t)=xst​[1−e−ζωn​t(cosωD​t+1−ζ2​ζsinωD​t​)]

  • xst=P0kx_{st}=\frac{P_0}{k}xst​=kP0​​
  • If undamped, x(t)=xst[1−cos⁡ωnt]x(t)=x_{st}[1-\cos\omega_nt]x(t)=xst​[1−cosωn​t]
  • Maximum value of x(t)/xst occurs when cos⁡ωnt=−1\cos\omega_nt=-1cosωn​t=−1

Undamped SDOF Response to a Rectangular Pulse

Rectangular pulse plot is seen below:

For t≤t1t\leq{t_1}t≤t1​, response is the same as for the step input. We know x(t)=P0[1−cos⁡ωnt]kx(t)=\frac{P_0[1-\cos\omega_nt]}{k}x(t)=kP0​[1−cosωn​t]​. When t>t1t>t_1t>t1​, or t=tˉt=\bar{t}t=tˉ, we have free vibration with initial conditions x(t1)x(t_1)x(t1​) and x(t1)˙\dot{x(t_1)}x(t1​)˙​. Thus, we have the below:

x(tˉ)=x(t1)cos⁡ωntˉ+x˙(t1)sin⁡ωntˉωnx(\bar{t})=x(t_1)\cos\omega_n\bar{t}+\frac{\dot{x}(t_1)\sin\omega_n\bar{t}}{\omega_n} x(tˉ)=x(t1​)cosωn​tˉ+ωn​x˙(t1​)sinωn​tˉ​

x(tˉ)=P0(1−cos⁡ωnt1)cos⁡ωntˉk+P0sin⁡ωnt1sin⁡ωntˉkx(\bar{t})=\frac{P_0(1-\cos\omega_nt_1)\cos\omega_n\bar{t}}{k}+\frac{P_0\sin\omega_nt_1\sin\omega_n\bar{t}}{k} x(tˉ)=kP0​(1−cosωn​t1​)cosωn​tˉ​+kP0​sinωn​t1​sinωn​tˉ​

See values at various t1T\frac{t_1}{T}Tt1​​

t1T\frac{t_1}{T}Tt1​​ Maximum response

Response Spectrum

Response spectrum: spectrum of natural frequency

During duration of rectangular pulse, response is AF=xmaxxst=1−cos⁡ωntAF=\frac{x_{max}}{x_{st}}=1-\cos\omega_ntAF=xst​xmax​​=1−cosωn​t. Maximum at t1T≥0.5\frac{t_1}{T}\geq{0.5}Tt1​​≥0.5 and maximum value is 2. Otherwise, the maximum will occur in the free vibration phase, such that after the end of the pulse, during the free vibration response phase, the amplification factor is AF=xmaxt−t1xst=cos⁡ωn(t−t1)−cos⁡ωnAF=\frac{x_{max_{t-t_1}}}{x_{st}}=\cos\omega_n(t-t_1)-\cos\omega_nAF=xst​xmaxt−t1​​​​=cosωn​(t−t1​)−cosωn​. Maximum found by setting derivative to zero, giving ∣AF∣=2sin⁡πt1T|AF|=2\sin\frac{\pi{t_1}}{T}∣AF∣=2sinTπt1​​. See below for response spectrum plot to rectangular pulse:

Impulsive Force

Impulsive force: large force that acts for very short duration of time. See dirac delta function below:

  • This is applicabe for small magnitude of ε\varepsilonε
  • For a unit impulse, the magnitude of impulse, or area under the curve, is ∫−∞∞δ(t−τ)=1\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\delta{(t-\tau)}=1∫−∞∞​δ(t−τ)=1
  • According to Newton's 2nd law, action of impulsive force on a mass changes the velocity of the mass, and hence its momentum. Change of momentum is equal to the impulse of the impulsive force. See below:

∫t1t2Fdt=m(x2˙−x1˙)=mΔx˙\int_{t_1}^{t_2}Fdt=m(\dot{x_2}-\dot{x_1})=m\Delta\dot{x} ∫t1​t2​​Fdt=m(x2​˙​−x1​˙​)=mΔx˙

∫−∞∞δ(t−τ)dt=mΔx˙t=τ=1\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\delta{(t-\tau)}dt=m\Delta{\dot{x}_{t=\tau}}=1 ∫−∞∞​δ(t−τ)dt=mΔx˙t=τ​=1

Δx˙t=τ=1m\Delta{\dot{x}_{t=\tau}}=\frac{1}{m} Δx˙t=τ​=m1​

Thus, the presence of an impulse force is synonymous with a velocity initial condition at t=τt=\taut=τ of magnitude 1 τ˙=1m\dot{\tau}=\frac{1}{m}τ˙=m1​. With the system vibration from the impulsive force, we have the below, with zero initial conditions:

x(t−τ)=sin⁡ωn(t−τ)mωn(Undamped free vibration)x(t-\tau)=\frac{\sin\omega_n(t-\tau)}{m\omega_n}\tag{Undamped free vibration} x(t−τ)=mωn​sinωn​(t−τ)​(Undamped free vibration)

x(t−τ)=e−ζωn(t−τ)sin⁡ωD(t−τ)mωD(Damped free vibration response)x(t-\tau)=\frac{e^{-\zeta\omega_n(t-\tau)}\sin\omega_D(t-\tau)}{m\omega_D}\tag{Damped free vibration response} x(t−τ)=mωD​e−ζωn​(t−τ)sinωD​(t−τ)​(Damped free vibration response)

If there are a general number of impulses, we have the following:

  • At any time t≥τt\geq{\tau}t≥τ, incremental response dx due to the impulse is equal to dx(t−τ)=P(τ)dτsin⁡ωn(t−τ)mωndx(t-\tau)=\frac{P(\tau)d\tau\sin\omega_n(t-\tau)}{m\omega_n}dx(t−τ)=mωn​P(τ)dτsinωn​(t−τ)​ (undamped system)
  • The total response at time t is given by superposing the response from all impulses from time τ=0\tau=0τ=0 to τ=t\tau=tτ=t such that x(t)=∫0tP(τ)sin⁡ωn(t−τ)dτmωnx(t)=\frac{\int_0^tP(\tau)\sin\omega_n(t-\tau)d\tau}{m\omega_n}x(t)=mωn​∫0t​P(τ)sinωn​(t−τ)dτ​ for undamped and x(t)=∫0tP(τ)e−ζωn(t−τ)sin⁡ωn(t−τ)dτmωnx(t)=\frac{\int_0^tP(\tau)e^{-\zeta\omega_n(t-\tau)}\sin\omega_n(t-\tau)d\tau}{m\omega_n}x(t)=mωn​∫0t​P(τ)e−ζωn​(t−τ)sinωn​(t−τ)dτ​ for damped. Generally, we have the below, with h being appropriate expression for the unit impulse function.

x(t)=∫0tP(τ)h(t−τ)dτ(Duhamel’s Integgral)x(t)=\int_0^tP(\tau)h(t-\tau)d\tau\tag{Duhamel's Integgral} x(t)=∫0t​P(τ)h(t−τ)dτ(Duhamel’s Integgral)

  • If P(t) is a simple mathematical function, solving this is quite possible.

If the conditions are not at rest, we have the following:

x(t)=x0cos⁡ωnt+v0sin⁡ωntωn+∫0tP(τ)sin⁡ωn(t−τ)dτmωn(Undamped)x(t)=x_0\cos\omega_nt+\frac{v_0\sin\omega_nt}{\omega_n}+\frac{\int_0^tP(\tau)\sin\omega_n(t-\tau)d\tau}{m\omega_n}\tag{Undamped} x(t)=x0​cosωn​t+ωn​v0​sinωn​t​+mωn​∫0t​P(τ)sinωn​(t−τ)dτ​(Undamped)

x(t)=e−ζωnt(x0cos⁡ωnt+v0sin⁡ωntωn)+∫0tP(τ)e−ζωn(t−τ)sin⁡ωn(t−τ)dτmωn(Undamped)x(t)=e^{-\zeta\omega_nt}(x_0\cos\omega_nt+\frac{v_0\sin\omega_nt}{\omega_n})+\frac{\int_0^tP(\tau)e^{-\zeta\omega_n(t-\tau)}\sin\omega_n(t-\tau)d\tau}{m\omega_n}\tag{Undamped} x(t)=e−ζωn​t(x0​cosωn​t+ωn​v0​sinωn​t​)+mωn​∫0t​P(τ)e−ζωn​(t−τ)sinωn​(t−τ)dτ​(Undamped)

Ramp Function Load

Ramp function load: load that increases linearly with time. See below:

The response is derived from Duhamel's integral; See unit 2 for more details

Step function load

A step function load with rise time is a load that rises linearly to P0P_0P0​ in time t1t_1t1​ and then remains constant. See below:

Since the rise function shouldn't exist when t>t1t>t_1t>t1​, a negative function is introduced Pˉ(t)=−P0(t−t1)t1\bar{P}(t)=\frac{-P_0(t-t_1)}{t_1}Pˉ(t)=t1​−P0​(t−t1​)​.

To solve the ramp function x(t), solve with Duhamel's integral x(t)=P0∫0t1τsin⁡ωn(t−τ)dτt1mωnx(t)=\frac{P_0\int_0^{t_1}\frac{\tau\sin\omega_n(t-\tau)d\tau}{t_1}}{m\omega_n}x(t)=mωn​P0​∫0t1​​t1​τsinωn​(t−τ)dτ​​. It is found that x(t)=P0[tt1−sin⁡ωntt1ωn]kx(t)=\frac{P_0[\frac{t}{t_1}-\frac{\sin\omega_nt}{t_1\omega_n}]}{k}x(t)=kP0​[t1​t​−t1​ωn​sinωn​t​]​ from 0≤t≤t10\leq{t}\leq{t_1}0≤t≤t1​. Then add negative function component to obtain full solution.

Since maximum response occurs when t≥t1t\geq{t_1}t≥t1​, find derivative of the response function.

This procedure can similarly be done with a sinusoidal function. See below for graphs depicting sinusoidal funcitons:

MDOF Systems

From the derivation in 3.1, the MDOF equation is sa below:

[m1000m2000m3][x1¨x2¨x3¨]+[C1+C2−C20−C2C2+C3−C30−C3C3][x1˙x2˙x3˙]+[k1+k2−k20−k2k2+k3−k30−k3k3][x1x2x3]=[P1(t)P2(t)P3(t)] \begin{bmatrix} m_1 & 0 & 0\\ 0 & m_2 & 0\\ 0 & 0 & m_3 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} \ddot{x_1}\\ \ddot{x_2}\\ \ddot{x_3} \end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix} C_1+C_2 & -C_2 & 0\\ -C_2 & C_2+C_3 & -C_3\\ 0 & -C_3 & C_3 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} \dot{x_1}\\ \dot{x_2}\\ \dot{x_3} \end{bmatrix}+ \begin{bmatrix} k_1+k_2 & -k_2 & 0\\ -k_2 & k_2+k_3 & -k_3\\ 0 & -k_3 & k_3 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x_1\\ x_2\\ x_3 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} P_1(t)\\P_2(t)\\P_3(t) \end{bmatrix}⎣⎡​m1​00​0m2​0​00m3​​⎦⎤​⎣⎡​x1​¨​x2​¨​x3​¨​​⎦⎤​+⎣⎡​C1​+C2​−C2​0​−C2​C2​+C3​−C3​​0−C3​C3​​⎦⎤​⎣⎡​x1​˙​x2​˙​x3​˙​​⎦⎤​+⎣⎡​k1​+k2​−k2​0​−k2​k2​+k3​−k3​​0−k3​k3​​⎦⎤​⎣⎡​x1​x2​x3​​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​P1​(t)P2​(t)P3​(t)​⎦⎤​

This is also Mx¨+Cx˙+kx=P(t)M\ddot{x}+C\dot{x}+kx=P(t)Mx¨+Cx˙+kx=P(t)

Assuming the solution [x1x2]=[X1X2]sin⁡(ωnt+α)\begin{bmatrix}x_1\\x_2\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}X_1\\X_2\end{bmatrix}\sin{(\omega_nt+\alpha)}[x1​x2​​]=[X1​X2​​]sin(ωn​t+α). For free vibration (P1(t)=P2(t)=0P_1(t)=P_2(t)=0P1​(t)=P2​(t)=0), the determinate is solved (3.11) and ωn\omega_nωn​ is determined to be ωn2=(k1+k2m1+k2m2)±(k1+k2m1+k2m2)2−4k1k2m1m22\omega_n^2=\frac{(\frac{k_1+k_2}{m_1}+\frac{k_2}{m_2})\pm\sqrt{(\frac{k_1+k_2}{m_1}+\frac{k_2}{m_2})^2-4\frac{k_1k_2}{m_1m_2}}}{2}ωn2​=2(m1​k1​+k2​​+m2​k2​​)±(m1​k1​+k2​​+m2​k2​​)2−4m1​m2​k1​k2​​​​. There will be two roots; these are the 2 undamped natural frequencies. The lower value is the first, or fundamental, circular natural frequency.

Mode shape vectors are determined by normalizing the movement to that of a unit movement. Letting β=X1X2\beta=\frac{X_1}{X_2}β=X2​X1​​, this vector is ϕi=(1β1)\phi_i=\begin{pmatrix}1\\ \beta_1\end{pmatrix}ϕi​=(1β1​​).

Important properties are as follows:

  • M and K are real and positive definite; eigenvalues are real
  • Stiffness matrix and modes are orthogonal
  • Mode shape vectors (eigenvectors) are absolutely indeterminate, but determinate relative to each other
  • Mass modal matrix is mormalized as shown in example 3.5

To solve free vibration response:

  1. Solve ωn\omega_nωn​
  2. Letting equations of motion of masses equal zero, solve for X1X_1X1​ and X2X_2X2​
  3. Solve β1\beta_1β1​ with fundamental frequency and β2\beta_2β2​ with next natural frequency
  4. Solve mode shape vectors ϕ1\phi_1ϕ1​ and ϕ2\phi_2ϕ2​, letting each XiX_iXi​ equal 1
  5. Write system as per 3.24

Important facts on matrices:

  1. m and k are symmetric. MT=MM^T=MMT=M and kT=kk^T=kkT=k
  2. For system w/o rigid body, m and k are positive definite matrices

Eigenvector review

Ax=λxAx=\lambda{x}Ax=λx, with AAA being a vector and λ\lambdaλ being a scalar. Taking the transpose, Aty=λyA^ty=\lambda{y}Aty=λy and [AT−λI]y[A^T-\lambda{I}]y[AT−λI]y. The transpose of both sides leads to the following:

yiTA=λiyiT(3.36)y_i^TA=\lambda_iy_i^T\tag{3.36} yiT​A=λi​yiT​(3.36)

Axj=λjxj(3.37)Ax_j=\lambda_jx_j\tag{3.37} Axj​=λj​xj​(3.37)

Post-multiplying 3.36 by xjx_jxj​ and pre-multiplying 3.37 by yiTy_i^TyiT​, we get yiTAxj=λiyiTjy_i^TAx_j=\lambda_iy_i^TjyiT​Axj​=λi​yiT​j and yiTAxj=λjyiTxjy_i^TAx_j=\lambda_jy_i^Tx_jyiT​Axj​=λj​yiT​xj​. The difference is seen below:

(λi−λj)yiTxj=0(\lambda_i-\lambda_j)y_i^Tx_j=0 (λi​−λj​)yiT​xj​=0

Since λi≠λj\lambda_i\neq{\lambda_j}λi​=λj​, we know yiTxj=0y_i^Tx_j=0yiT​xj​=0. Thus, if y and x are distinct "left" and "right" eigenvectors, they are orthogonal. Additionally, if A is symmetric, they are the same. Thus, eigenvectors are linearly independent and can be written as linear combinations of N eigenvectors of A. Letting u be an arbitrary vector,

U=C1xi+C2x2U=C_1x_i+C_2x_2 U=C1​xi​+C2​x2​

To determine coefficients, premultiply by yiTy_i^TyiT​. See below:

yiTu=CiyiTxiy_i^Tu=C_iy_i^Tx_i yiT​u=Ci​yiT​xi​

Ci=yiTuyiTxiC_i=\frac{y_i^Tu}{y_i^Tx_i} Ci​=yiT​xi​yiT​u​

For undamped N-DOF systems, the following applies:

Solving for 3.51 yields N real and positive roots for ωn2\omega_n^2ωn2​. From this, eigenvectors can be found from 3.50. However, these must be relative, not absolute. Eigenvectors ϕn\phi_nϕn​ correspond to the response amplitude and are called the mode shape vectors.

To determine natural frequency:

  1. Solve eigenvalue problem
  2. Find roots
  3. Plug in roots to solve for mode shape vectors

Orthogonality Property

Following the eigenvalue problem Kϕn=ωn2MϕnK\phi_n=\omega_n^2M\phi_nKϕn​=ωn2​Mϕn​, we say that for Mode i, Kϕn,i=ωn,i2Mϕn,iK\phi_{n,i}=\omega_{n,i}^2M\phi_{n,i}Kϕn,i​=ωn,i2​Mϕn,i​ and for Mode j, Kϕn,j=ωn,j2Mϕn,jK\phi_{n,j}=\omega_{n,j}^2M\phi_{n,j}Kϕn,j​=ωn,j2​Mϕn,j​. By pre-multiplying the former by ϕn,jT\phi^T_{n,j}ϕn,jT​ and the latter by ϕn,iT\phi^T_{n,i}ϕn,iT​, we get the following:

ϕn,jTKϕn,i=ωn,i2ϕn,jTMϕn,i(3.59)\phi^T_{n,j}K\phi_{n,i}=\omega_{n,i}^2\phi^T_{n,j}M\phi_{n,i}\tag{3.59} ϕn,jT​Kϕn,i​=ωn,i2​ϕn,jT​Mϕn,i​(3.59)

ϕn,iTKϕn,j=ωn,j2ϕn,iTMϕn,j(3.60)\phi^T_{n,i}K\phi_{n,j}=\omega_{n,j}^2\phi^T_{n,i}M\phi_{n,j}\tag{3.60} ϕn,iT​Kϕn,j​=ωn,j2​ϕn,iT​Mϕn,j​(3.60)

Taking transpose of both sides in 3.59 yields ϕn,iTKϕn,j=ωn,i2ϕn,iTMϕn,j\phi^T_{n,i}K\phi_{n,j}=\omega^2_{n,i}\phi_{n,i}^TM\phi_{n,j}ϕn,iT​Kϕn,j​=ωn,i2​ϕn,iT​Mϕn,j​. Subtracting from 3.60, we get:

(ωn,j2−ωn,i2)ϕn,iTMϕn,j=0(\omega_{n,j}^2-\omega_{n,i}^2)\phi_{n,i}^TM\phi_{n,j}=0 (ωn,j2​−ωn,i2​)ϕn,iT​Mϕn,j​=0

It thus follows that ϕn,iTMϕn,j=0\phi_{n,i}^TM\phi_{n,j}=0ϕn,iT​Mϕn,j​=0 for all modes; this is the mass orthogonality property. Subbing back into 3.60, we also get that ϕn,iTKϕn,j=0\phi_{n,i}^TK\phi_{n,j}=0ϕn,iT​Kϕn,j​=0 for the modes. This demonstrates that the stiffness matrix is orthogonal. In addition, by pre-multiplying 3.58 by ϕn,iT\phi_{n,i}^Tϕn,iT​, the following is shown:

ϕn,iTKϕn,iϕn,iTMϕn,i=ωn,i2\frac{\phi_{n,i}^TK\phi_{n,i}}{\phi_{n,i}^TM\phi_{n,i}}=\omega_{n,i}^2 ϕn,iT​Mϕn,i​ϕn,iT​Kϕn,i​​=ωn,i2​

Kϕn,i=ωn,i2Mϕn,iK\phi_{n,i}=\omega_{n,i}^2M\phi_{n,i} Kϕn,i​=ωn,i2​Mϕn,i​

The modal matrix can make things easier. See below:

Φ=[ϕ11ϕ12ϕ1Nϕ21ϕ22ϕ2NϕN1ϕN2ϕNN]=[ϕn,1,ϕn,2,ϕn,N]\Phi=\begin{bmatrix} \phi_{11} & \phi_{12} & \phi_{1N}\\ \phi_{21} & \phi_{22} & \phi_{2N}\\ \phi_{N1} & \phi_{N2} & \phi_{NN}\end{bmatrix} =[\phi_{n,1},\phi_{n,2},\phi_{n,N}]Φ=⎣⎡​ϕ11​ϕ21​ϕN1​​ϕ12​ϕ22​ϕN2​​ϕ1N​ϕ2N​ϕNN​​⎦⎤​=[ϕn,1​,ϕn,2​,ϕn,N​]

The modal matrix is only known in the relative sense. It is typical to normalize these modes such that Mii=ϕiTMϕiM_{ii}=\phi_i^TM\phi_iMii​=ϕiT​Mϕi​ (mass normalization). On a vector scale, the following is obtained:

ΦTMΦ=I\Phi^TM\Phi=I ΦTMΦ=I

ΦTKΦ=[ωn,12000ωn,22000ωn,N2]=Λ\Phi^TK\Phi=\begin{bmatrix}\omega_{n,1}^2&0&0\\0&\omega_{n,2}^2&0\\0&0&\omega_{n,N}^2\end{bmatrix}=\Lambda ΦTKΦ=⎣⎡​ωn,12​00​0ωn,22​0​00ωn,N2​​⎦⎤​=Λ

To determine mass normalized modes Φ=[ϕ1,ϕ2]\Phi=[\phi_1,\phi_2]Φ=[ϕ1​,ϕ2​] given a mass matrix and natural modes:

  1. Take each column of the modal matrix as a respective ϕn\phi_nϕn​, with ϕ1=αψ\phi_1=\alpha\psiϕ1​=αψ and ϕ2=βψ\phi_2=\beta\psiϕ2​=βψ
  2. Solve for α\alphaα and β\betaβ

Mode Superposition

From before, we know x=[x1x2⋮xN]=∑i=1NϕiAisin⁡(ωn,it+αi)=∑i=1Nϕi(aicos⁡ωn,it+bisin⁡ωn,it)x=\begin{bmatrix}x_1\\x_2\\\vdots\\x_N\end{bmatrix}=\sum_{i=1}^N\phi_iA_i\sin{(\omega_{n,i}t+\alpha_i)}=\sum_{i=1}^N\phi_i(a_i\cos\omega_{n,i}t+b_i\sin\omega_{n,i}t)x=⎣⎡​x1​x2​⋮xN​​⎦⎤​=∑i=1N​ϕi​Ai​sin(ωn,i​t+αi​)=∑i=1N​ϕi​(ai​cosωn,i​t+bi​sinωn,i​t). Resulting from the modal matrix, we have:

x=[ϕ11ϕ12…ϕ1Nϕ21ϕ22…ϕ2N⋮⋮⋱⋮ϕN1ϕN2…ϕNN][a1cos⁡ωn,1t+b1sin⁡ωn,1ta2cos⁡ωn,2t+b2sin⁡ωn,2t⋮aNcos⁡ωn,Nt+bNsin⁡ωn,Nt]=Φyx=\begin{bmatrix} \phi_{11} & \phi_{12} & \ldots & \phi_{1N}\\ \phi_{21} & \phi_{22} & \ldots & \phi_{2N}\\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ \phi_{N1} & \phi_{N2} & \ldots & \phi_{NN} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} a_1\cos\omega_{n,1}t+b_1\sin\omega_{n,1}t\\ a_2\cos\omega_{n,2}t+b_2\sin\omega_{n,2}t\\ \vdots \\ a_N\cos\omega_{n,N}t+b_N\sin\omega_{n,N}t\\ \end{bmatrix} = \Phi{y}x=⎣⎡​ϕ11​ϕ21​⋮ϕN1​​ϕ12​ϕ22​⋮ϕN2​​……⋱…​ϕ1N​ϕ2N​⋮ϕNN​​⎦⎤​⎣⎡​a1​cosωn,1​t+b1​sinωn,1​ta2​cosωn,2​t+b2​sinωn,2​t⋮aN​cosωn,N​t+bN​sinωn,N​t​⎦⎤​=Φy

Plugging into Mx¨+Kx=0M\ddot{x}+Kx=0Mx¨+Kx=0, we get MΦy¨+KΦy=0M\Phi\ddot{y}+K\Phi{y}=0MΦy¨​+KΦy=0. Pre-multiplying by ΦT\Phi^TΦT, we then get ΦTMΦy¨+ΦTKΦy=0\Phi^TM\Phi{\ddot{y}}+\Phi^TK\Phi{y}=0ΦTMΦy¨​+ΦTKΦy=0. This is written as follows:

Iy¨+Λy=0I\ddot{y}+\Lambda{y}=0 Iy¨​+Λy=0

There are now lo longer vector quantities, but N SDOF systems with yN¨+ωn,N2yN=0\ddot{y_N}+\omega^2_{n,N}y_N=0yN​¨​+ωn,N2​yN​=0. Keep in mind that the undamped SDOF solution is y(t)=y0,1cos⁡ωn,1t+y0,1˙sin⁡ωn,1tωn,1y(t)=y_{0,1}\cos\omega_{n,1}t+\frac{\dot{y_{0,1}}\sin\omega_{n,1}t}{\omega_{n,1}}y(t)=y0,1​cosωn,1​t+ωn,1​y0,1​˙​sinωn,1​t​

  • y0=[y0,1,y0,2…y0,N]y_0=[y_{0,1},y_{0,2}\ldots{y_{0,N}}]y0​=[y0,1​,y0,2​…y0,N​] is initial displacements
  • y0˙=[y0,1˙,y0,2˙…y0,N˙]\dot{y_0}=[\dot{y_{0,1}},\dot{y_{0,2}}\ldots\dot{{y_{0,N}}}]y0​˙​=[y0,1​˙​,y0,2​˙​…y0,N​˙​] is initial velocities

To relate the initial displacements and velocities, the relationships y0=ΦTMx0y_0=\Phi^TMx_0y0​=ΦTMx0​ and y0˙=ΦTMx0˙\dot{y_0}=\Phi^TM\dot{x_0}y0​˙​=ΦTMx0​˙​ are used.

To find solution for 2DOF system, given initial x displacement:

  1. Find equations of motion and mass/stiffness matrices
  2. Solve for ωn\omega_nωn​ through the determinate
  3. Find natural modes assuming X1=1X_1=1X1​=1
  4. Determine mass normalized modes
  5. Convert initial displacements/velocity to y plane and determine solution
  6. Transform back to physical coordinates

Damped MDOF Systems

In the damped case with Mx¨+Cx˙+Kx=0M\ddot{x}+C\dot{x}+Kx=0Mx¨+Cx˙+Kx=0, assuming x=Φy\Phi{y}Φy, we can say Iy¨+ΦTCΦy˙+Λy=0I\ddot{y}+\Phi^TC\Phi\dot{y}+\Lambda{y}=0Iy¨​+ΦTCΦy˙​+Λy=0 This is only uncoupled with ΦTCΦ\Phi^TC\PhiΦTCΦ is diagonal; this will be shown below.

When C is proportional, it is possible to uncouple the equations of motion using the undamped modes. Any other form of the damping matrix is known as non-proportional damping.

In mass-proportional damping, C=αMC=\alpha{M}C=αM, with α\alphaα being proportionality factor. From the properties of M, this means ΦTCΦ=αI\Phi^TC\Phi=\alpha{I}ΦTCΦ=αI, and is diagonal.

In stiffness-proportional damping, C=βKC=\beta{K}C=βK, with β\betaβ being proportionality factor. From the properties of K, this means ΦTCΦ=βΛ\Phi^TC\Phi=\beta\LambdaΦTCΦ=βΛ, and is diagonal.

In Rayleigh damping, the damping matrix is related to both mass and stiffness C=αM+βKC=\alpha{M}+\beta{K}C=αM+βK. As before, it can be shown that ΦTCΦ=αI+βΛ\Phi^TC\Phi=\alpha{I}+\beta\LambdaΦTCΦ=αI+βΛ, and is diagonal.

Note the following:

To determine α\alphaα, as per the above, if ζ\zetaζ and ω\omegaω are given, then α\alphaα can be solved. However, only one α\alphaα can be used. Once it is hcosen, the damping ratio for the second mode can be determined.

α1=2ζ1ωn,1(3.130)\alpha_1=2\zeta_1\omega_{n,1}\tag{3.130} α1​=2ζ1​ωn,1​(3.130)

Similarly, to determine β\betaβ, only one value is allowed.

β1=2ζ1ωn,1(3.135)\beta_1=\frac{2\zeta_1}{\omega_{n,1}}\tag{3.135} β1​=ωn,1​2ζ1​​(3.135)

For Rayleigh, it is a similar process. See below:

β=2[ζ1ωn,1−ζ2ωn,2]ωn,12−ωn,22(3.141)\beta=\frac{2[\zeta_1\omega_{n,1}-\zeta_2\omega_{n,2}]}{\omega_{n,1}^2-\omega_{n,2}^2}\tag{3.141} β=ωn,12​−ωn,22​2[ζ1​ωn,1​−ζ2​ωn,2​]​(3.141)

α=2ζ1ωn,1−βωn,12(3.142)\alpha=2\zeta_1\omega_{n,1}-\beta\omega_{n,1}^2\tag{3.142} α=2ζ1​ωn,1​−βωn,12​(3.142)

α=2ζ2ωn,2−βωn,22(3.143)\alpha=2\zeta_2\omega_{n,2}-\beta\omega_{n,2}^2\tag{3.143} α=2ζ2​ωn,2​−βωn,22​(3.143)

See relationship between these variables below:

To solve for damped, the response equation is similar to that from earlier for damped system. See below:

yN=e−ζNωn,Nt(y0,Ncos⁡ωD,Nt+y0,N˙+y0,NζNωn,NωD,Nsin⁡ωD,Nt)(3.147)y_N=e^{-\zeta_N\omega_{n,N}t}(y_{0,N}\cos\omega_{D,N}t+\frac{\dot{y_{0,N}}+y_{0,N}\zeta_N\omega_{n,N}}{\omega_{D,N}}\sin\omega_{D,N}t)\tag{3.147} yN​=e−ζN​ωn,N​t(y0,N​cosωD,N​t+ωD,N​y0,N​˙​+y0,N​ζN​ωn,N​​sinωD,N​t)(3.147)

  • ωD,i=ωn,i1−ζi2\omega_{D,i}=\omega_{n,i}\sqrt{1-\zeta_i^2}ωD,i​=ωn,i​1−ζi2​​

To solve equations of motion for 2DOF system, given M and K matrix and initial conditions andd ζ\zetaζ

  1. Determine natural frequencies from characteristic equation
  2. Mass normalized modes
  3. Solve for α\alphaα and/or β\betaβ
  4. Plug in to equations to find C
  5. Plug into response equation
  6. Find in physical coordinates

In Caughey Damping, we can show that ΦTCΦ=α0I+α2Λ+α2Λ2\Phi^TC\Phi=\alpha_0I+\alpha_2\Lambda+\alpha_2\Lambda^2ΦTCΦ=α0​I+α2​Λ+α2​Λ2. It is also possible to solve for any number of modes if their ζ\zetaζ values are known with the direct method.
